Award.AwardTitle: The Worst Journey in the World - Graphic Novel
Award.AbstractNarration:
The artist is producing a serialized graphic novel adaptation of The Worst Journey in the World, Apsley Cherry-Garrard's memoir of the Terra Nova Expedition, in partnership with the Scott Polar Research Institute. This series will introduce the story to a new generation, in an accessible and factually fastidious retelling which foregrounds the expedition's scientific endeavors, the prologue to the scientific work being done by the NSF in Antarctica today. Having already thoroughly researched the historical record, the artist is going to Antarctica to visit the important locations of the expedition, most notably Cape Evans, Hut Point, and Cape Crozier, with visits to or flights over the Beardmore Glacier and the environs of One Ton Depot if weather and operations allow. The aim is to get as full a sense as possible of the environments in which the history played out -- both topographically and experientially -- in order to depict Antarctica as truthfully and evocatively as possible to a wide audience. This research trip will be fully documented and shared (after returning) on the artist's social media. The finished books will be full-color comics with substantial annotations, including information on how the work done in 1910-13 relates to the modern scientific program.

The artist will be based at McMurdo Station, and from there make day trips to Cape Evans, Cape Crozier, the Ross Ice Shelf, and potentially fly over the Beardmore Glacier on a return flight to the Pole. The historic huts at Cape Evans (ASPA 155), Hut Point (ASPA 158) and Cape Crozier (ASPA 124) and visits to Arrival Heights (ASPA 122) will be thoroughly documented in photographs and sketches, as will the areas around McMurdo Station and Scott Base. Flyovers will be documented in photos and video. Travel to Cape Evans and the Ross Ice Shelf will be via snowmobile, and to Cape Crozier via helicopter; flights to the Beardmore/Pole and near 79S (where One Ton Depot was located) will be by helo or fixed-wing aircraft, as opportunity arises. There will be four books in the series, which will average around 250 pages, being approximately 2/3 narrative comic and 1/3 factual endnotes. The endnotes will cite sources and provide supplementary information. The research and development of the project is already being shared online, and it is expected that the finished work will get online distribution before transferring to print. The first volume will be released in late 2020, with succeeding volumes in following years.
This is an Antarctic Artists and Writers project supported by NSF's Office of Polar Programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Apsley Cherry-Garrard's memoir of the Terra Nova Expedition, The Worst Journey in the World, has touched millions since its publication in 1922.  It is a classic of travel literature, inspiring readers with its description of the extremes endured for the sake of science, and the heights the human spirit can achieve in adversity. 

The aim of my graphic adaptation is to bring this story to new audiences in a compelling and accurate way. Thanks to the NSF I have visited the primary locations - Cape Evans, Hut Point, Cape Crozier, and the Beardmore Glacier, among others - and will be able not only to present them with physical accuracy, but bring readers into what it feels like to be there. Contacts made with scientists and heritage experts on this research trip will ensure in-depth background knowledge to everything I depict. Relationships formed with various countries' polar programs will help promote the project internationally, and to communities who may not otherwise be interested in graphic novels.

The Worst Journey in the World: Graphic Novel is currently in production, and the first volume will likely be released in 2022. More immediately, the vast amount of reference I collected, both historical and scientific, is being presented to the public through my blog (twirlynoodle.com/blog) where my photographs are shared with comprehensive written context, bringing readers to a deeper understanding of Antarctica, both in the Heroic Age and now. As one of the few visually-oriented historians to visit some of these key locations, I am able to illustrate specific points in the historical record with targeted photos that have, hitherto, not been publicly available. People who already have an interest in the subject will have their understanding expanded, and new audiences get that understanding from the outset.

Scientific knowledge has advanced considerably in the last hundred years, but the scientist explorers of the early 20th century still have much to teach us about persevering in difficulty, living up to our ideals, and cooperating constructively even in times of stress and hardship.  Their story proves that science can be as exciting as any action movie.  By engaging emotionally with my cinematic presentation of the material, and its immersive depiction of the continent, readers will develop an emotional attachment to Antarctica too, and engage with modern Antarctic science and conservation.

  • The view into the main area of the Cape Evans hut, from the bunks known as 'the Tenements'. Apsley Cherry-Garrrad's bunk was down and to the right. See the geologists' cubicle across the table � I had not found any exterior photos of this before visiting.
    Sarah Airriess
    Sarah J Airriess
    View from the Tenements
  • The view south from Wind Vane Hill. There was visual communication between Cape Evans and Hut Point via flares, and from here interested parties could see whether cloud patterns over Minna Bluff indicated a coming blizzard. I had hitherto been unable to find a photo of this essential vista.
    Sarah Airriess
    Sarah J Airriess
